data.title: PHILIPPINES: AQUINO'S CALL TO BOYCOTT MARCOS-CONNECTED BUSINESSES TAKES AFFECT.
data.meta_description: Search and license clips from Reuters vast archive of news video footage, dating back to 1896
data.text: Title: PHILIPPINES: AQUINO'S CALL TO BOYCOTT MARCOS-CONNECTED BUSINESSES TAKES AFFECT. Summary: FEBRUARY 20 & 21 1. GV EXTERIOR Makati Stock Exchange building 0.05 2. SCU Makati Stock Exchange, trading floor sign 0.08 3. GVs Stock Exchange shares board empty, phones ringing. (2 SHOTS) 0.14 4. SCU Chalk mark on board saying shares in commodity suspended pending listing. 0.17 5. SV & GV Man picking up and answering phone. Board in stock exchange. (2 SHOTS) 0.24 FEBRUARY 21 6. SCU Doctor Hilarion Henares, former chairman of Economic Council and of Philippine Chamber of Industries, speaking. (English SOT) 1.11 FEBRUARY 20 & 21 7. GV TILT DOWN & GV EXTERIOR Combank building, demonstrators outside with banners marching. (2 SHOTS) 1.27 8. SV Demonstrators carrying placards supporting Corazon Aquino. 1.36 9. GVs EXTERIOR Allied Bank, with demonstrators marching past. (2 SHOTS) 1.42 10. GV PULL BACK Demonstrators outside Rustan super store. 1.46 11. GV & SV Demonstrators with banners, including one saying "Boycott Cronies". (2 SHOTS) 1.53 12. GV Demonstrators singing as effigy burns. 2.05 TRANSCRIPT: HENARES: (SEQ 6) "Well you know capital is extremely cowardly. It flees at the first sign of problem. And the boycott is trouble. It's affected the confidence of the foreign investor, the foreign debtor and especially the Filipino capitalist. Secondly, this is only the beginning. Cory is just testing her strength. If she can get the people to support her, then by God Marcos is in trouble and the economy too." REPORTER: "How involved are Marcos' cronies in the Philippine economy?" HENARES: "Oh very, very much so. They're involved in the major export sectors, coconut and sugar. They're also involved in most of the utilities, electricity, telephones, etc. They are involved in the biggest businesses there are. They go down perhaps the economy is going to be a real, real trouble." InitialsRM/JS Script is copyright Reuters Limited. All rights reserved Embargoed: 11th March 1986 12:00 Keywords: Location: MANILA, PHILIPPINES Country: Philippines Topics: General Reuters ID: LVA2BW1XU7O2UTPVS3SGOQ4ZBYFA Story Text: MANILA, PHILIPPINES The call by Philippines leader Corazon Aquino on February 16 for her followers to boycott banks, businesses and newspapers owned or controlled by President Ferdinand Marcos' friends or associates, has begun to bite. Aquino claimed she won the February 7 presidential elections but was cheater of her victory by fraud and intimidation on the part of Marcos. The withdrawal of large sums of money from banks, and the fall in share prices on such prominent companies as the Philippines biggest food and beverage conglomerate "San Miguel Corporation", has led foreign investors to think twice about putting their money into the country. The situation was not helped when the Philippine Central Bank suddenly declared February 24 to be a bank holiday for no apparent reason. The Manila stock exchange also closed on that day, so halting the capital's money market and foreign exchange dealings. Former Chairman of the Philippines Economic Council and Chamber of Industries, Dr. Hilarion Henares thought the boycott which was affecting foreign investors' confidence not to mention Filipino capitalists, was only the beginning. He said that if Aquino could get the people's support, Marcos and the economy would be in serious trouble. Tension in the country heightened on February 24 after Marcos declared a state of emergency and sanctioned the use of small arms by loyalist forces to defend important positions. Marcos and his 'cronies' according to Dr. Henares owned or were involved in all the country's major businesses and export sectors. Already thousands of students have banded together to form non-violent protests outside the so called 'cronie' banks belonging to Marcos or his associates. Consumer groups have also been formed to back Cory Aquino's boycott. Meanwhile the International Monetary Fund (I.M.F.) has shown concern about the amount of money that was spent funding President Marcos' re-election campaign. Source: REUTERS - MANUEL SILVA Copyright Holder: REUTERS Copyright Notice: (c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2015.
